report_title: Peer-to-Peer Lending Platforms in the US
executive_summary: Peer-to-peer (P2P) lenders' revenue has remained stagnant but climbed slightly at a CAGR of 0.0% to $1.7 billion over the five years to 2024, including an expected increase of 3.2% in 2024 alone. Pioneered and introduced in the United Kingdom in 2005, P2P lending platforms facilitate loans from individual investors that pool their money via operators' online platforms to loan money to consumers and small businesses. The industry's competitive advantage lies in its proprietary credit evaluation algorithms, which go beyond FICO credit scores used by traditional lending institutions.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Pandemic Has a Lingering Effect on Peer-to-Peer (P2P) Lending
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: - P2P revenue declined substantially in 2020 as unemployment shot up in the same year. Overall, revenue fell 43.8% in 2020 alone. - The increased economic uncertainty and drop in consumer confidence pushed clients back to traditional financial institutions in the first year of the pandemic. - In an uncertain climate, investors withdrew capital from P2P platforms in 2020. - Revenue has been increasing since 2020, but a big drop during the pandemic limited overall growth over the past five years.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Interest Rates Have Been Experiencing Fluctuations
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: - In 2020, the Federal Reserve brought interest rates to historical lows in response to the pandemic. With lower rates, consumers felt more comfortable using new fintech services like P2P but low interest rates meant less interest fees earned by P2P lenders, hurting revenue growth. - Many P2P lender start-ups used the low-rate environment to invest and expand operations which helped the industry grow following the pandemic.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Fears of Hyperinflation Spurs Interest Rate Hikes
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Following the pandemic, the Federal Reserve has raised interest rates to tackle high inflation. With higher rates, P2P lenders were able to receive higher interest fees earned, which has resulted in revenue growth for the industry every year following the pandemic. Supply chain issues and a global energy crisis created historically high inflation. In 2022, the Federal Reserve began hiking interest rates to control inflation. Higher interest rates are reducing liquidity in the financial markets. The P2P lender start-ups that use debt to sustain growth are likely to face serious hardship if rates keep increasing.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Investor Uncertainty Will Likely Decline for the Next Few Years
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Inflation is still too high, and the Federal Reserve is determined to keep rates high to stop it. However, the Federal Reserve is considering to cut interest rates at the onset of the outlook period. If the Fed isn't careful, it might cause a recession or let inflation fears get entrenched. The Federal Reserve must still monitor high inflation. The decline in investor uncertainty will limit revenue declines for the industry and be an opportunity for operators.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: High Interest Rates Are Expected to Limit New Entrants
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: A lot of P2P lenders are start-ups dependent on the flow of cheap money. Sustained high rates will likely have negative effects on an industry where most P2P lenders aren't even profitable. The problems of high interest rates in both the finance and technology sector will converge and apply even more pressure on this fintech industry.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Cryptocurrency and the Blockchain Will Likely Shape the Industry
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: If the crypto sphere survives the current economic environment, it will play a big role in peer-to-peer lending. P2P lending platforms can be a meeting place for investors and lenders on a blockchain. Smart contracts on a blockchain network will make peer-to-peer lending services safer and faster. Opportunities for innovation will limit revenue declines moving forward.

market_segmentation.segment_description: A key example of a relatively untapped market satisfied by peer-to-peer (P2P) lending is represented by recent graduates dubbed as "high earners, not rich yet" (HENRYs). Loans from students and recent graduates are popular since many in this group have low traditional credit scores. P2P lenders use of nontraditional methods of determining credit worthiness make it easier for this segment to take out loans.

More home and real estate buyers are looking to P2P lenders for mortgages. As liquidity dries up in the financial markets, some home and real estate buyers might seek nontraditional financial institutions for mortgages at better rates.
Other consumers makes the biggest market for P2P lenders. Other consumers comprise over three-fifths of industry revenue in the current year.

This market consists of businesses. Most businesses that have good credit would rather use traditional financial institutions, although businesses that don't have good credit would consider peer-to-peer lending platforms. As P2P lenders get more established and trusted, businesses will likely increase in market size.

products_and_services.product_description: Consumers with low credit scores, paying high interest, seek P2P lenders for potentially better rates. Consumers with low credit scores typically seek for alternatives to traditional banks. P2P lenders proprietary algorithms are used to check credit worthiness at a faster rate than traditional credit checking methods.

Consumer loans are loans to non-business consumers for various reasons. P2P lending platforms base their business models on expanding credit access to those that can't qualify for a loan from a traditional financial institution. If interest rates keep rising this segment will decrease in size, but likely bring in more revenue for P2P lenders.

Business lending is loans to businesses. Property lending is loans for property purchases. Growth in business and property lending has driven growth in this segment. Business loans from P2P lenders are increasing as the industry becomes more established and trusted.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Aggregate household debt includes all outstanding credit market debt held by consumers, including credit card debt, mortgages and personal loans. Industry interest revenue increases when consumers choose to borrow more money and hold higher debt levels. Aggregate household debt is also highly correlated with consumer sentiment, which affects the level of debt consumers choose to hold. Declines in aggregate household debt pose a potential threat to the industry.

The prime rate refers to the interest rate that commercial banks charge their most creditworthy customers and largest corporate clients. A low prime rate usually boosts bank loan demand under nonrecessionary conditions, resulting in lowered demand for nontraditional loans. Declines in the prime rate will boost bank loan demand.

Businesses are an increasingly significant customer group for P2P lending platforms. Business sentiment and corporate profit determine demand for credit, the quality of lending portfolios and the level of financing transactions. An increase in corporate profit is expected to positively affect operators by increasing loan demand, and therefore, transaction fees.

Rising investor uncertainty negatively affects the level of trading in financial instruments. In the short term, rising investor uncertainty over economic conditions boosts trading volumes as investors seek to limit their losses or exit investments. However, over the long term, prolonged investor uncertainty drives investors away from financial markets. Investor uncertainty is expected to increase.

The number of broadband connections represents the total number of internet connection points with speeds greater than 200.0 kilobits per second in at least one direction and includes both households and businesses. As more consumers and businesses have high-speed internet connections, P2P lending platforms, which are based online, will likely have more opportunities to reach potential borrowers. Growth in the number of broadband connections represents an opportunity for the industry.

business_locations.location_description: Peer-to-peer lenders depend on the technological advancements from Silicon Valley. There are lots of venture capital firms in the bay area investing in start-ups, like P2P lenders. California is the state with the most P2P lenders.
New York is the most highly concentrated state within this region. Some start-up companies begin in New York since it's the financial headquarters hub of the United States.

The Southeast is close to investment sources and offers relatively low start-up costs. Kabbage Inc., among the first to enter the industry, was founded in Atlanta, and still maintains significant operations in Georgia. The company is the leading P2P small business lender in the Southeast.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The Truth in Lending Act (TILA) protects consumers when doing business with lenders and creditors. Lenders must be clear when offering financial products and services. There are several disclosure requirements that P2P platforms must disclose such as the annual percentage rate (APR), total loan costs and P2P lenders must disclose a payment schedule.

The ECOA prohibits creditors from discriminating against applicants with respect to their race, color, religion and other reasons that would violate their civil liberties. The ECOA ensures that all consumers are given an equal opportunity to obtain credit. P2P lending platforms must ensure that credit evaluations do not discriminate against applicants.

The FCRA promotes the privacy and accuracy of consumer information used for consumer reporting agencies. This law protects consumers from malicious or negligent inclusion of incorrect data in their credit reports. Operators rely on credit reports to evaluate customers. The FCRA ensures that this information is up to date.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The Peer-to-Peer(P2P) Lending Platforms industry is heavily regulated, with strict laws and regulations. Lenders face the same regulations and restrictions as traditional lending institutions.

Establishing a new P2P lending platform requires significant investment in technology, capital and other resources. This can be a challenge for new entrants, especially in the face of established competitors with economies of scale and established customer bases.
New entrants need to differentiate themselves from existing competitors. This increases the difficulty of establishing a foothold in the market and attracting customers.

FAQs.question: How do you emphasize the value of your company's services?
FAQs.answer: Businesses can emphasize the value of their services by touting the use of algorithms and new lending practices. Businesses can emphasize the value of their services touting the number of loans originated and the return delivered to investors.

FAQs.question: How has the shift toward conducting business online affected demand for your services?
FAQs.answer: The shift toward conducting business online has benefited the industry to a substantial degree. This industry is very much related to the 'trust economy' or sharing economy, which is very much online based.

FAQs.question: What international operations do you conduct, and how could you benefit from increasing your international reach?
FAQs.answer: Very few companies operate outside the United States due to size and regulatory complications. OnDeck, a business loan provider, operates in Canada.

FAQs.question: Are your operations spread across the country or are they more concentrated in a certain geographic location?
FAQs.answer: Given the online nature of industry operations, lending is very much spread out across the country. Large companies in the industry have lent funds to customers in all 50 states.

FAQs.question: How have you taken advantage of rising online and mobile penetration into the financial services industry?
FAQs.answer: Rising online and mobile penetration into the financial services industry has benefited the industry because it is online-based. Major lending platforms have mobile apps that allow investors and consumers to track loans.

FAQs.question: To what extent are your processes automated? How much do you plan on investing in automation over the coming years?
FAQs.answer: The credit evaluation process is largely automated and this is the industry's competitive advantage. Companies in this industry invest in automation to a large extent.

FAQs.question: How have the increased capital requirements under Basel III affected your operations?
FAQs.answer: Basel III does not affect this industry.

FAQs.question: How do you expect the proposed changes to Dodd-Frank might affect your business?
FAQs.answer: Rollbacks to Dodd-Frank do not affect this industry in a material way.

FAQs.question: How do your profit margins compare to those of your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Most operators within this industry are not profitable due to their status as startups or emerging businesses. Profit is difficult to compare as most companies are private.

FAQs.question: Do you have enough capital reserved to be able to invest in new technology/software as soon as it becomes available?
FAQs.answer: In most cases, companies have enough money to invest in new technology, as venture capital funding is popular with this industry.

FAQs.question: How quickly can new technology be adopted? Does your company keep up to date with the latest technology?
FAQs.answer: As the way consumers interface online changes with the advent of new devices such as smartphones and tablets, successful operators will be able to deliver new platforms from which consumers can interact with the company.

FAQs.question: Which niches, if any, do you cater to? How can you diversify your product mix?
FAQs.answer: Operators have experienced some success in marketing to specific demographics, such as college students, small businesses and seniors.

FAQs.question: How does your company go about managing various kinds of risk? How effective are these techniques?
FAQs.answer: Successful operators will have methods of scrutinizing loan prospects and determining which ones are the most credit-worthy, resulting in lower default rates.
